The post Should I use Free VPN appeared first on Steve T Inc.
item.content:encoded:
Using VPN is quite a popular thing in the world of today to get access to restricted content on the internet but the real question is it worth it and what are the dangers of using free VPN.oky lets start

The term free just speaks for its self something thats not going to  be reliable (free tip:if you ever think of hacking any back,company or anything never use vpn)


Oky guys first of all my point of argument is that why they is a paid version????. My answer is that because of a free version they only give you maybe one server and put all other servers and write pro only…. so what does this mean -this actually means its not free at all,they are just using it to advertise their real vpn so i recommend not to trust and use vpn when doing something like hacking our any other thing.


Other thing speaking from experience my ip adress was once blocked on Wikipidia and i decided to download free vpn and guess what did it work or not -(Short answer is no) the VPN ddnt work at all.

When ever you want real vpn try a premium version of the vpn because its fast,reliable,and safe.

The post Should I use Free VPN appeared first on Steve T Inc.

item.title: 5 Most Dangerous hackers in The World
item.dc:creator: Steve T Inc
item.description:

The post 5 Most Dangerous hackers in The World appeared first on Steve T Inc.
item.content:encoded:
1)Kevin MitnickÂ  .An original figure in American hacking, Kevin Mitnick got his beginning as a high schooler. In 1981, he was accused of taking PC manuals from Pacific Bell. In 1982, he hacked the North American Defense Command (NORAD), an accomplishment that enlivened the 1983 film War Games. In 1989, he hacked Digital Equipment Corporation’s (DEC) organize and made duplicates of their product.

2)anonymous

The group started in 2003 on 4chan message sheets in an anonymous gathering. The gathering displays little association and is approximately centered around the idea of social equity. For instance, in 2008 the gathering disagreed with the Church of Scientology and start impairing their sites, in this way contrarily affecting their inquiry rankings in Google and overpowering its fax machines with every single dark picture. In March 2008, a gathering of “Anons” walked passed Scientology revolves the world over wearing the now-renowned Guy Fawkes cover.

3)Adrian Lamo :

driÃ¡n Alfonso Lamo Atwood  (February 20, 1981 â€“ March 14, 2018) was an American threat analyst and hacker. Lamo first gained media attention for breaking into several high-profile computer networks, including those of The New York Times, Yahoo!, and Microsoft culminating in his 2003 arrest.

Lamo was best known for reporting U.S. soldier Chelsea Manning to Army criminal investigators in 2010  for leaking hundreds of thousands of sensitive U.S. government documents to WikiLeaks. Lamo died on March 14, 2018 at the age of 37. source

4)Jeanson James Ancheta :On May 9, 2006, Jeanson James Ancheta (born 1985) became the first person to be charged for controlling large numbers of hijacked computers or botnets. source

5)Matthew Bevan and Richard Pryce :Mathew Bevan (born 10 June 1974) is a British hacker from Cardiff, Wales. In 1996 he was arrested for hacking into secure U.S. Government networks under the handle Kuji. At the age of 21, he hacked into the files of the Griffiss Air Force Base Research Laboratory in New York. source

5)Michael Calce  :(born 1986, also known as MafiaBoy) is a security expert and former computer hacker from ÃŽle Bizard, Quebec who launched a series of highly publicized denial-of-service attacks in February 2000 against large commercial websites, including Yahoo!, Fifa.com, Amazon.com, Dell, Inc., E*TRADE, eBay, and CNN.  He also launched a series of failed simultaneous attacks against nine of the thirteen root name servers.

The post 5 Most Dangerous hackers in The World appeared first on Steve T Inc.
